content.title: Premium-quality local beer at Basz Bar

introduction.small: Near Vienna's Wettstein Park, Basz Bar calls for friendly gatherings at pre-dinner, with a few Austrian beers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Premium-quality local beer at Basz Bar

paragraphs.text:
Even though Austrians are among the largest consumers of beer in the world, they tend to show little interest in their own production: the country is not even part of the top 10 European producers. To put an end to this fact and most importantly pay tribute to national beer, Basz Bar offers a small selection dedicated to local microbreweries, with quality Austrian names like Schnaitl and Rieder. It also presents a selection of other wines and spirits from the Vienna region. Regulars share a homemade liquor or cocktail, like the Basz Fusion (hot pepper and cinnamon-infused vodka, mixed with beer and ginger), to be enjoyed in moderation obviously. With its wooden tables, bench seats covered in pillows and flickering candles, this beer bar rather looks like a modern tea salon. A subdued atmosphere for a sweet and intimate moment.

Basz Bar
Hollandstraße 7
1020 Vienna

+43 676 428 3678

www.basz-bar.at ﻿

Menu: beer from 3.90 EUR

content.title: Blue Mustard, a culinary journey across the world

introduction.small: In the heart of the historic city centre, next to St. Stephen's Cathedral, this gastronomic bar offers a high-end and original food and cocktail selection.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Blue Mustard, a culinary journey across the world

paragraphs.text:
Let the explorer in you transform your palate into the vessel that will take you on a gustatory journey across the world. The modern and cosmopolitan universe of Blue Mustard in Vienna can be traced both in the decoration and on the menu. Under the intimate and subdued lighting filtered by wooden latticework (reminiscent of the Arabian mashrabiya), you will discover a fusion menu, blending traditional dishes from world cuisine with local products.
This journey is available in four or five courses. Each carries the name of a city: Dijon for the coq au vin, crystallised celery and mushroom cream, Jerusalem for an eastern lamb tartare with zaatar, labneh and braised eggplant, and Malé for the wild rockfish in coconut served with lentils in curry and marinated green papaya. This undeniably refined inventory of world gastronomy earned Blue Mustard its first Michelin star.

Blue Mustard
Dorotheergasse 6-8
1010 Vienna

+43 1 93 46 705

www.bluemustard.at/?lang=en

Menu: around 44 EUR

content.title: Rejuvenation at Therme Wien

introduction.small: Therme Wien, Vienna's thermal baths, are the perfect place to recharge your batteries, alone or with the family.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rejuvenation at Therme Wien

paragraphs.text:
The Romans were already enthusiasts of the sulphurous waters of Vienna nearly two thousand years ago. With two springs with a sulphur content of 62.4 and 64 mg/litre, they are the most therapeutic thermal baths in Europe. Therme Vien has taken advantage of this attribute to provide a place of relaxation and total well-being where you will return to your old self.
The establishment is organised into different zones to allow you to move around easily, according to your needs and desires: a “beauty” area to pamper yourself from head to toe, an area dedicated to silence for a moment of inner calm, an adventure area for children to play, a sauna, and a fitness centre.
Outside, athletes train by swimming 25-metre lengths. Therme Wien is a haven of peace, where your children won't lack exercise, thanks to a dedicated and supervised environment, while you take time to yourself, all to yourself…

Therme Wien
Kurbadstraße 14
1100 Wien

+43 (0)1 68009 9600

http://www.thermewien.at/en/

content.title: In the footsteps of Gustav Klimt in Vienna

introduction.small: Discover famous Symbolist painter Gustav Klimt and admire his works exhibited almost everywhere in Vienna.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In the footsteps of Gustav Klimt in Vienna

paragraphs.text:
Follow in the footsteps of Klimt, the Art Nouveau artist who left his footprints all over Vienna. Begin your journey at Burgtheater, where the artist painted the ceilings and staircases: here, he recreated the Ancient theatre of Taormina in Sicily, where he depicted the Globe Theatre in London and a scene from Romeo and Juliette. Continue towards the Museum of Art History, and particularly the stairs of the establishment that decorate the spandrels between columns where 40 paintings await you.
At the Pavilion of the Secession, a basement room is dedicated to the famous Beethoven Frieze, a 34-metre-long interpretation of the musician's Ninth Symphony. Then head to the Wien Museum, on Karlsplatz, which exhibits some of Klimt's works such as Emilie Flöge, a portrait of his life companion, and Pallas Athena. Two other museums hold the painter's works: the Leopold Museum and MAK (Museum of Applied Arts). Last but not least, finish your walk at the Belvedere to admire The Kiss, his most famous work, adorned with gold and silver, as well as Judith and Adam and Eve.

Burgtheater
Universitätsring 2
1010 Vienne

Kunsthistorisches Museum Wien (Museum of Art History)
Maria-Theresien-Platz
1010 Vienne

Secession Wien (Pavilion of the Secession)
Friedrichstraße 12
1010 Vienne

Wien Museum
Karlsplatz 8
1040 Wien

Leopold Museum
Museumsplatz 1
1070 Vienne

MAK Wien (Museum of Applied Arts)
Stubenring 5
1010 Vienne

www.burgtheater.at/en
www.khm.at/en
www.wienmuseum.at/en.html
www.leopoldmuseum.org/en
www.mak.at/en

content.title: National Opera

introduction.small: Vienna's National Opera (Wiener Opernball) hugely varied repertoire makes it a must for all lovers of the lyrical art form.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: National Opera

paragraphs.text:
The National Opera house in Vienna, long under the direction of the late, legendary Herbert von Karajan, has established itself as one of the greatest opera houses in Europe. Its repertoire ranges from the Baroque to the 21st century, with a high priority for the music of the 19th century.
The building, virtually destroyed during the war, was rebuilt, identically, to its original specifications. For its first show in 1955, it presented Beethoven's Fidelio. If you are not able to obtain seats—it is best to book well in advance—you can, however, enjoy a guided tour. You will see the grand marble staircase, the foyer, backstage areas, and the great curtain created by the artist Dominique Gonzalez-Foerster. In spring and in September, 150 performances are projected live onto a 50-square-metre screen in front of the square—a free show that is very much appreciated.

National Opera
Opernring 2
1010 Vienna

+43 1 513 1513

www.wiener-staatsoper.at

content.title: Das Triest: a former coaching inn converted into a charming hotel

introduction.small: The Hotel Das Triest is a successful mix of old stone and contemporary design, as envisioned by Sir Terence Conran.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Das Triest: a former coaching inn converted into a charming hotel

paragraphs.text:
Three hundred years ago, it was a coaching inn for wayfarers on the road connecting Vienna to Trieste. It is now a boutique hotel with 72 rooms, where the old stables have been transformed into lounges, suites, and meeting rooms.

British designer Sir Terence Conran has created an elegant space around a courtyard blooming with flowers in summer. This four-star has all the signs of greatness. The large rooms are beautifully furnished: the beds with wooden headboards, the chests of drawers of 30s inspiration and antique taps in the white tiled bathrooms. The toiletries from Molton Brown add a touch of refinement. Some suites overlook the garden, which you can choose if you are in need of quiet.

Das Triest
Wiedner Hauptstrasse 12
1040 Vienna

+43 1 589 180

www.dastriest.at

Rooms: from 139 EUR

content.title: Zum Schwarzen Kameel: from morning to night, always excellent

introduction.small: You can come at any time and be certain that you will be received well, but more especially, you can taste one of the excellent specialities.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Zum Schwarzen Kameel: from morning to night, always excellent

paragraphs.text:
This place has been open for 400 years, which is certainly enough to boast a rich past. Originally, it was a dairy-grocery store. Over the years, the house has grown along with its reputation.

So much so that it is now busy from cocktail hour until the last glass. The owner is proud of his recipes, often those of his mother. The menu changes each month, but the specialities remain. From one of the renowned Kameel sandwiches, accompanied by a glass of wine at the bar, to a more invigorating meal in the dining room, with wood panelling among the more recent additions to the place (20th century), there is something to please everyone.

In summer, the sidewalk terrace welcomes guests, and everywhere, the atmosphere is warm. The only challenge is not to overindulge on the delicious wines carefully selected by the sommelier.

Zum Schwarzen Kameel
Bognergasse 5
1010 Vienna

+43 1 533 8125

www.kameel.at

Menu: around 68 EUR

content.title: The Prater: trees, a Ferris Wheel, and amusements

introduction.small: The Prater has been a Viennese favourite for two centuries. People come to walk and get some fresh air, but they also come to have fun.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Prater: trees, a Ferris Wheel, and amusements

paragraphs.text:
Emperor Joseph II opened this former imperial hunting reserve on the Danube to the public in 1766. Since then, it has been a huge recreational and relaxation area, where many sports facilities have been built. On one side is the carnival, with nearly 250 attractions, and on the other is one of the favourite places for the Viennese to stroll.

Walkers and joggers take advantage of its shady paths, vast lawns, and grasslands. In bygone days, carriages would parade past, but today people prefer to walk or picnic among the trees.

The Giant Ferris Wheel, built in 1896-97 and famous for the film The Third Man, dominates the city from a height of 64.75 meters. Damaged by fire in 1944, it now comprises only 15 pods instead of 30.

Giant Ferris Wheel
Riesenradplatz 1
1020 Vienna

+43 (0)1 729 5430

www.wienerriesenrad.com

content.title: Hotel Sacher: a timeless legend

introduction.small: Impeccable, authentic, exemplary, the Hotel Sacher has been one of the most famous palaces of Vienna for more than a century.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Sacher: a timeless legend

paragraphs.text:
Built near the opera in 1876 by Eduard Sacher, the Hotel Sacher is one of the legendary hotels of old Europe, a hotel proud of its traditions and its antique furniture.

Over the years, it has lost none of its lustre. Never mind that the decoration of the 149 rooms and suites seems a little charged, with over a thousand art works, rich hangings, sumptuous bouquets of flowers and crystal chandeliers. It is timelessly beautiful, especially since its renovation by the French interior designer Pierre-Yves Rochon. An antique atmosphere still reigns in its felt-clad lounges, reminiscent of a time when Vienna shone on the world stage through its writers and musicians.

John Lennon and Yoko Ono gave a press conference on peace from their bed here, and, according to legend, the Sachertorte, the famous chocolate cake, was invented here. A cup of tea at the hotel bar is a fine accompaniment to this intensely rich cake. Such luxury is obviously expensive, but the souvenirs you will keep of this opulent palace are something to cherish.

Hotel Sacher
Philarmoniker Strasse 4
1010 Vienna

+43 1 514 560

www.sacher.com

Rooms: from 374 EUR

content.title: Sigmund Freud Museum : In the footsteps of psychoanalysis

introduction.small: Freud lived in Vienna for decades and you can visit his house. He treated his patients and also wrote many of his influential books in there.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sigmund Freud Museum : In the footsteps of psychoanalysis

paragraphs.text:
It is here, on two floors of an elegant building, where the inventor of psychoanalysis lived and received his patients between 1891 and 1938, before being rushed into exile in England under the pressure of Nazism.

He died in London the following year. Sigmund Freud had his office in the family apartment. One of his best-known books, The Interpretation of Dreams, was written in this apartment. A museum was built in the 1970s with the help of Anna, his youngest daughter.

On display are some furniture, personal items, letters, books, and antiques, though, unfortunately, the couch is only a copy, the original having remained in London.

Sigmund Freud Museum
Berggasse 19
1090 Vienna

Tel : +43 (0)1 319 1596

www.freud-museum.at

content.title: Viennese cafés: Coffee in all its forms

introduction.small: The Viennese frequent cafés several times a day. Imitate them and you too will succumb to these improvised stops.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Viennese cafés: Coffee in all its forms

paragraphs.text:
Vienna has been a city of cafés for three centuries, with one located on virtually every corner. It is a tradition that is well established in the country's mores. Intellectuals, politicians, artists like Klimt, Schnitzler, Freud, and Zweig, were all regulars at these places. Though cafés had their heyday in the 19th and 20th centuries, they are still very popular.

People go to these quiet, spacious rooms at almost any time of day to chat, read the newspapers, meet friends, or just relax. And the range of coffees is immense, from the basic Schwarzer or Mokka (black) to kleiner Brauner (with a little milk) mit Schlag (with whipped cream) and Turkischer (with the grains). But coffee alone is like wine without cheese, so most often it is accompanied with one of the many pastries, such as apple strudel. Some of these cafés are very famous, like the Café Central, Café Prückel, Café Diglas, Café Jelinek, Café Sacher, and Café Sperl,

whose common points are elegant surroundings and beautiful design with a patina of age.

Café Central
Herrengasse 14
1010 Vienna

+43 (0)1 533 3763

www.cafecentral.wien/en/

content.title: Hollmann Beletage: a hotel keeper who cooks

introduction.small: In a renovated 19th century building, the warm welcome of this hotel makes it feel like home.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hollmann Beletage: a hotel keeper who cooks

paragraphs.text:
Robert Hollmann was an actor who became a hotelier. And it's a good thing he did, because his hotel has a warm, welcoming atmosphere. Discreetly tucked away on the first floor of an historic building of the old city, it offers 25 spacious, modern rooms. Take the time to read a book from the library in the salon while the fire crackles in the fireplace, then head straight to the restaurant.

The menu is renewed daily and features fresh seasonal products from the organic farms in the region. The owner is an excellent cook and will not only feed you, but also make you feel well. If you feel sociable, you can join the communal table to converse with your neighbours, or dine on the lovely terrace.

To finish off the evening in style, settle into the small hotel cinema to watch Carol Reed's film, The Third Man, written by and starring Orson Welles, shot on location in Vienna in 1948.

Hollmann Beletage
Köllnerhofgasse 6
1010 Vienna

+43 1 961 1960

www.hollmann-beletage.at

Rooms: from 169 EUR

content.title: Schönbrunn: the ‘Austrian Versailles'

introduction.small: The summer residence of the Habsburgs is sumptuous. The visit, which includes the castle and the park, is an appointment with imperial history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Schönbrunn: the ‘Austrian Versailles'

paragraphs.text:
Schönbrunn Palace, one of the most beautiful Baroque palaces in Europe situated in south-west Vienna, was the summer residence of the Habsburgs, and one of Emperor Franz Joseph's favourite places.

After the fall of Napoleon, his wife, the Archduchess Marie Louise, and her son, the King of Rome lived there and in 1832, he died there. In this room we can see what he referred to as the only friend he ever had: a stuffed bird. But such melancholy is quickly overcome by the palatial rooms, which testify to the splendour of the court, including, among others, the Chinese Salon and the Grand Gallery, where a great many banquets were held.

After visiting the castle, the immense park is beautiful with its ruins, flowerbeds, gazebo, ponds, and statues. For botanical enthusiasts, there is also a collection of thriving tropical plants in the great greenhouse.

Schönbrunn Palace
Schönbrunner Schlosstrasse 47
1130 Vienna

+43 (0)1 811 13-239

www.schoenbrunn.at

content.title: Saint-Stephen's Cathedral: its spire is the soul of the city

introduction.small: The building of St. Stephen's Cathedral, more commonly known as ‘Stephansdom', began in the 13th century, and it is a must. The roofing, the sculptures everything is beautiful.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saint-Stephen's Cathedral: its spire is the soul of the city

paragraphs.text:
The largest Gothic building in the whole of Austria with a spire that rises to 137 metres is considered by the Viennese to be the symbol of their city. From the towers, one has a breath-taking view of the city. Its roof is covered with 250,000 diamond-shaped polychrome tiles. Construction of the cathedral lasted for two centuries, but it was badly damaged during World War II.

The majestic interior contains treasures such as the stone-carved pulpit, the altarpiece representing the Virgin between St. Catherine and St. Barbara, and the altar built in 1640. Stained glass from the Middle Ages, representing the Passion, illuminates the choir with their strong colours.

According to legend, Beethoven realised he had gone deaf when he saw birds flying away from the tower without hearing the noise of the bells.

Stephansdom
Stephansplatz 3
1010 Vienna

+43 1 515 523 054

www.stephanskirche.at

content.title: Sofitel Vienna Stephansdom

introduction.small: Minimalist design in three colours: white, grey, and black. The hotel, designed by architect Jean Nouvel, is surprising and seductive.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sofitel Vienna Stephansdom

paragraphs.text:
Located on the banks of the canal, this recently opened hotel is a daring glass tower inspired by St Stephen's cathedral. It therefore enjoys a superb view of the city centre. This is particularly true in the gourmet restaurant at the top of the building.

With delicious cuisine overseen by the three-star French chef Antoine Westermann, you may also admire the vibrantly colourful ceiling 10 metres above your table, painted by a Swiss artist. The contrast is striking with the minimalism of Jean Nouvel's architecture: 182 rooms including 26 suites are uniformly white, grey, or black from floor to ceiling, which is a surprising concept at first, but you get used to it very quickly.

For an exceptional outing, the concierge can arrange a carriage ride with Champagne and a picnic.

Sofitel Vienna Stephansdom
Praterstrasse 1
1020 Vienna

+43 1 906 160

www.sofitel-vienna-stephansdom.com

Rooms: from 275 EUR

content.title: Steirerek: two Michelin stars for what many consider Vienna's best

introduction.small: An elegant, high-end kitchen and perfect service all go together to make this a memorable experience.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Steirerek: two Michelin stars for what many consider Vienna's best

paragraphs.text:
It is very expensive, certainly, but it is also sumptuous. This restaurant has won two Michelin stars, and is rated 15th in San Pellegrino's 50 best restaurants in the world. The chef Heinz Reibauer trained with French chef Alain Chapel and Swiss chef Anton Mosimann, and, along with his wife Birgit, offers a warm welcome at this elegant, ultra-modern restaurant in the park.

Reitbauer builds on the best of Austrian cuisine to concoct combinations of bold flavours that sometimes hold a few surprises. All products are of impeccable quality, coming from selected suppliers, or the family farm. You will also be seduced by the choice of breads and the cheese tray, without forgetting the many desserts. The service is worthy of a palace and does not suffer the slightest criticism.

A small card accompanying each dish describes its composition. You may keep it as a taste memory, which is a nice touch.

Steirerek
Am Heumarkt 2A/
1030 Vienna

+43 1 713 3168

www.steirerek.at

Menu: around 100 EUR

content.title: Skopik & Lohn: eating well under an artistic ceiling

introduction.small: In this restaurant we are far from the traditional and conventional, so go there for the innovative cooking and the decor.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Skopik & Lohn: eating well under an artistic ceiling

paragraphs.text:
This bistro in the trendy Karmelitermarkt quarter opened nearly ten years ago and has since attracted a steady stream of gourmets. It has an excellent reputation for serving Viennese cuisine with a French accent, and the prices are very reasonable considering the quality of the food.

The clientele is eclectic, as many artists like this place, and there is a reason for this. The decor, chosen by the owner Horst Scheuer, is dominated by a work of art that gives the restaurant its originality.

The ceiling, painted by the artist Otto Zitko, also extends over the walls. According to its admirers, it's a graphic fresco or nothing but black squiggles if you believe its detractors. Whatever the fresco may do for you, this restaurant is charming, the welcome stylish, and the service efficient.

Skopik & Lohn
Leopoldgasse 17
1020 Vienna

+43 1 219 8977

www.skopikundlohn.at

Menu: around 30 EUR

content.title: Do & Co Hotel Vienna: very fashionable steel and glass

introduction.small: The outstanding view of St. Stephen's Cathedral and the decoration of the rooms are the two main features of this hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Do & Co Hotel Vienna: very fashionable steel and glass

paragraphs.text:
Launched some ten years ago and located close to St. Stephen's Cathedral, the hotel still features among the most fashionable places of the Austrian capital. The hotel has a high return ratio and there are several reasons for this.

While the superb views of the cathedral are certainly part of the draw, the decoration of the 43 rooms and suites also comes into play. The stylish and chic Italian designed furniture, the most up-to-date stereo equipment, blond wood floors and elegant teak and stone bathrooms offer a high level of elegance and comfort.

The Onyx Bar on the sixth floor may be considered the heart of the establishment, where you can sip delicious cocktails while listening to the latest music. The restaurant meanwhile serves excellent cuisine with a predominately Asian influence, all in a contemporary setting.

Do & Co Hotel Vienna
Stephanplatz 12
1010 Vienna

+43 (0)1 24 188

www.docohotel.com

Rooms: from 299 EUR

content.title: Salonplafond im MAK: an original concept that stimulates the taste buds.

introduction.small: A superb setting and a quality menu are the two main qualities of this restaurant you'll rightly want to visit.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Salonplafond im MAK: an original concept that stimulates the taste buds.

paragraphs.text:
The former restaurant on this site run by chef Helmut Osterreicher has given way to the Salonplafond im MAK (140 seats). With new décor and a new kitchen, it took more than three months of work and 1.3 million Euros for the renovations. While the coffered ceiling has been preserved, the furniture has been modernized, and the overall atmosphere is also pleasant and comfortable.

This was also the aim of the designers, to make it a favourite of the Viennese but also for tourists. So, you can come at any time, from breakfast through till evening for a drink at the bar. The kitchen, supervised by the great German chef Tim Mälzer, has been entrusted to Aaron Walti who worked with him for two years in his restaurant in Hamburg.

He practices traditional Viennese cuisine but revisits it with contemporary touches and pastries are given pride of place. By Spring, it will be possible to have lunch in the garden.

Salonplafond im MAK
Stubenring 5
1010 Vienna

+43 1 226 0046

www.salonplafond.wien/en/

Menu: around 35 EUR

content.title: Hofburg: The Imperial Palace in the footsteps of the Habsburgs

introduction.small: The Hofburg is composed of a set of buildings with magnificent architecture that comprises a city unto itself.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hofburg: The Imperial Palace in the footsteps of the Habsburgs

paragraphs.text:
For six centuries the Hofburg was the seat of power. The winter residence of the Habsburgs has over 2,600 rooms and 18 wings. Enlarged and rebuilt over the ages, it has Gothic, Baroque, and Neoclassical influences.

If you're short on time, stick to visiting the 20 rooms of the royal apartments. Starting in the footsteps of Emperor Franz Joseph and his wife, the beautiful Sissi, visit the dining room, smoking room, the courtroom, and the great salon where a stately portrait of the Empress painted by Winterhalter hangs.

It was in his study that Franz Joseph learned of the death of his son Rodolphe. Classical concerts waltzes and Mozart operas in particular are given between May and December.

Hofburg Imperial Palace
Michaelerkuppel
1010 Vienna

+43 (0)1 533 7570

www.hofburg-wien.at

content.title: Albertina: the most beautiful collection of drawings in the world

introduction.small: The Albertina Museum features thousands of masterpieces in its permanent collection, but it also features consistently great temporary exhibitions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Albertina: the most beautiful collection of drawings in the world

paragraphs.text:
Set in the historic heart of Vienna, the Albertina houses the world's largest collection of drawings of the great masters of painting: Dürer's famous Young Hare may be seen there alongside works by Rembrandt, Raphael, Van Gogh, and many other artists from the Middle Ages right through until the 20th century.

In short, only masterpieces, coming largely from the collection assembled in 1776 by the son of the Empress Maria Theresa. It was he, Prince Albert Casimir August of Saxony, Duke of Teschen, who commissioned the building in 1801, hence the name of the museum. Restored in 2003, it is a superb and unforgettable experience.

One can also visit the richly furnished ceremonial rooms that vividly evoke the culture of the court, though the admirable wooden marquetry of rosewood and ebony is so fragile that it is forbidden to visit in rain or snow.

Albertina Museum
Albertinaplatz 1
1010 Vienna

+43 (0)1 534 830

www.albertina.at

content.title: Attractions of all kinds for children

introduction.small: Exploring Vienna is child's play. Explore the zoo, get lost in a maze, and go wild at the funfair.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Attractions of all kinds for children

paragraphs.text:
Vienna is a great family destination. Most museums are free for children, as is transport. Tour the Ring by tram, the circular road around the city. But you may also choose a horse-drawn carriage, a ride in a vintage bus, or a boat ride on the river.

Attractions and distractions are innumerable. Visit the Schönbrunn Zoo where more than 500 species of animals, especially lions, Siberian tigers, and hippos live. If your children are tired, a small panoramic train circulates freely. The nearby maze may also amuse them, as well as the Prater Fair.

In fine weather, there are hiking trails all around the city, where you may picnic before returning to the hotel. For food lovers big and small, discover all of chocolate's secrets at the Chocolate Museum, before moving on to the tasting.

Tourist-Info Wien
Albertinaplatz
1010 Vienna

+43 (0)1 245 55

www.wien.info/en

content.title: Plachutta: the king of boiled beef

introduction.small: A temple of Viennese cuisine, this is where you must come to eat local specialities, notably the famous Tafelspitz. Excellent.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Plachutta: the king of boiled beef

paragraphs.text:
Plachutta is one of the stars of traditional Viennese cuisine, as evidenced by the numerous books best sellers that the chef has written. His speciality: Tafelspitz, a kind of stew with vegetables (leeks, carrots, onions…) served in a copper pot after simmering for at least three hours. Just like Emperor Franz Joseph, who claimed this as his favourite dish, everybody loves this typical Austrian recipe.

The room is always packed with families, businessmen, stars, who all come for lunch or dinner. Here you will appreciate not only the kitchen, but also the warm atmosphere.

In summer, a huge terrace can accommodate more guests.

Plachutta
Wollzeile 38
1010 Vienna

+43 1 512 1577

www.plachutta-wollzeile.at/en

Menu: around 45 EUR

content.title: Museumsquartier Wien, an oasis of culture

introduction.small: Museumsquartier is ​​the museum and gallery quarter, which may be visited for its architecture, but also for the masterpieces presented.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museumsquartier Wien, an oasis of culture

paragraphs.text:
The old stables of the Habsburgs gave way to a set of museums, inaugurated in 2001, which embodies Viennese artistic creativity. Baroque and sometimes very bold contemporary architecture coexist in harmony.

Visit the largest collection in the world dedicated to the tormented Egon Schiele, as well as the paintings of the prolific Gustav Klimt at the Leopold Museum, where over 5,000 works are on display over five floors of this almost windowless white cube. The Mumok, a dark basalt building featuring art from the first half of the 20th century, contains more than 7,000 works. Its large windows offer a magnificent view over Vienna. One can also see the Museum of Architecture and the Kunsthalle, dedicated to international contemporary art. The whole neighbourhood shows cultural experiences that are among the most innovative, so soak it all in.

Take your time and do not hesitate to push open the door of a gallery, listen to an impromptu concert, or sit in one of the many neighbouring cafés and terraces.

Museumsquartier Wien
Museumsplatz 1
1070 Vienna

+43 (0)1 523 5881

www.mqw.at
